day01.title: Hello Auckland
day01.description: After traveling for 27 hours, we landed in the city of Auckland. First impression: there are a lot of Asians here, and diverse Asian food choices as a result.

images.caption: We went on a walking tour of the city. The Art Gallery museum was small but charming, so was Albert Park. Britomart was a beautiful area with string lights decoration and chic shops. High Street and Vulcane Lane were filled with hip store fronts.
We found Cafe Hanoi, an authentic Vietnamese bistro. I wish the portion was bigger because, look at that cha ca! (tumeric-seasoned pan seared fish served over vermicelli).
Can't stay on the ground for too long. I went to open silk training at Aracnation that evening.
There was some trouble navigating to the Fairy Falls hike but we made it. The waterfall was so worth the four hours round-trip, stairs and stream crossing. How could you resist view?
Delicious, healthy brunch at a place called Station Cafe. Not picture is the lattes and blueberry bread pudding we had for dessert. Yum.
We went up to the Sky Tower for a panoramic view of Auckland. It was a beautiful sunny day. Bonus: there was no line or crowd of people (hmm, Empire State Building).

We're off to the Coromandel Peninsula. The accommodation was a old-fashioned but well-equipped bungalow by the Hot Water Beach. The air was a bit chilly but the water under the sand was hot. So we dug our own hot tub.

day04.title: Cathedral Cove
day04.description: One can't come to the Coromandel Peninsula and not see Cathedral Cove. It was a good two-hour hike since we started at Hahei Beach.

images.caption: There was a beautiful mini tropical waterfall right on the beach. On the hike, we also passed a very windy grassland with a one-tree hill.
Climbing into a crevice despite the warning.
Gemstone Bay, where the stones were round and colorful, and Stingray Bay with amazing blue water.

day05.title: The Lost World adventure
day05.description: I'd never thought I'd done something this adventurous.

images.caption: We lowered from the rope 100 meters down into the cave. The air was so misty it felt like being engulfed in a soft mist pillow. The sharp vertical rock edges and lush greenery contributed to the feeling of descending into a 'lost world' as the original explorers had described.
Inside the pitch-black cave, we sat still and watched glow worms (fly larvea) as the sound of flowing water echoed through.
